Percent of Wisconsin residents fully vaccinated

Daily doses per 1 million Wisconsin residents
(7-day averages)

phases.phaseRequirements: Frontline healthcare workers, nursing home residents and staff, and residents and staff at assisted-living facilities.

Police, fire personnel and correctional staff were first eligible in Phase 1B, which then expanded to people 65 and older.

Part two of 1B began March 1 and includes:

  • Education and child care workers
  • People in Medicaid long-term care programs such as IRIS and Family Care
  • Public-facing essential workers, such as 911 operators, public transit workers, utility workers and food supply chain workers, including agricultural workers and retail food workers
  • Non-frontline health care personnel
  • People in congregate living, such as those in mental health institutions or people who are incarcerated
  • Mink husbandry workers
People ages 16 to 64 with high-risk medical conditions. (See more detailed information below)

questions.question: Who is currently eligible for the vaccine?
questions.answer:
Emergency authorization for the Pfizer vaccine was approved by the FDA for childeren ages 12 to 15 on May 10. Wisconsin is now vaccinating everyone 12 and over.

Health systems may prioritize those with high-risk medical conditions, including:

  • Asthma (moderate to severe)
  • Cancer
  • Cerebrovascular disease
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease)
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Down syndrome
  • Heart conditions, such as heart failure, coronary artery disease or cardiomyopathies
  • Hypertension or high blood pressure
  • Immunocompromised state from solid organ transplant, blood or bone marrow transplant, immune deficiencies, HIV, use of corticosteroids or use of other immune weakening medicines
  • Liver disease
  • Neurologic conditions such as dementia
  • Obesity or severe obesity
  • Overweight
  • Pregnancy
  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Type 1 or 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Thalassemia
questions.linkOne: What we know about Wisconsin's COVID-19 vaccine plan, who's eligible and when

questions.question: I'm not eligible for the vaccine. What can you tell me about when I will be?
questions.answer: As of May 10 the FDA has approved emergency use of the Pfizer vaccine for children ages 12 to 15. Clinical trials on children under 12 have started but no authorization has been given at this time.
questions.linkOne: What we know about Wisconsin's COVID-19 vaccine plan, who's eligible and when
questions.linkTwo: Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine proves safe and effective for kids ages 12 to 15, company study shows

questions.question: What is Wisconsin’s vaccine distribution plan?
questions.answer: Wisconsin health officials created a phased rollout plan that began with frontline healthcare workers and long-term care facilities in Phase 1A. The state is currently in Phase 1C, which includes people with underlying medical conditions that put them at risk for especially bad effects of COVID-19 (see list of conditions in previous question.) And everybody else will be in Phase 2.
questions.linkOne: What we know about Wisconsin's COVID-19 vaccine plan, who's eligible and when

categories.category: Where can I get the vaccine?

questions.category: Where can I get the vaccine?
questions.question: Does Wisconsin have a COVID vaccine registry?
questions.answer:
The state health department does have a centralized website to help people find vaccinators and schedule appointments in their local area. However, vaccinating providers have to opt into the website, so it will not be a comprehensive resource for all vaccination options.  

Separately, the department has created a map to show the public where vaccine clinics and providers are located, with links to provider websites.
questions.linkOne: Wisconsin's promised vaccine registry site has launched with just one vaccinator while state works out glitches

questions.category: Where can I get the vaccine?
questions.question: I’m eligible for the vaccine. How do I schedule my appointment?
questions.answer:
Health care providers, local and retail pharmacies, community health centers, local health departments, standup vaccine clinics and even some supermarket chains are offering the vaccine – but it can be hard to know where to look.

We’ve published a list of places administering the vaccine across the state, along with information about how to sign up at each one.
questions.linkOne: How a group of Wisconsin 'vaccine hunters' are helping eligible people find and get shots

questions.category: Where can I get the vaccine?
questions.question: Where can I get a vaccine?
questions.answer:
There are several kinds of places that are providing vaccinations in Wisconsin:

  • Health systems. Most are calling eligible patients to schedule appointments
  • Community health centers. Most are calling patients or scheduling appointments online or over the phone
  • Walgreens. Appointments can be made online or by calling 1-800-925-4733.
  • Meijer. You can get on a list for a vaccine appointment online, by texting COVID to 75049 or by calling or visiting your local Meijer pharmacy.
  • Metro Market. Some Kroger grocery stores with pharmacies are receiving the vaccine. Visit metromarket.net/rx/covid-eligibility to check availability.
  • Pick 'N Save. Some Kroger grocery stores with pharmacies are receiving the vaccine. Visit picknsave.com/rx/covid-eligibility to check availability.
  • Some local pharmacies. Many independent pharmacies have ways to register for a vaccine on their websites or to put your name on a waiting list. Others have set up walk-in vaccination clinics. Go here for more.
  • County and city health departments. Information is available on their websites.
  • Community vaccine clinics. There are three state-sponsored community clinics open in the state, as well as other large-scale vaccine clinics in the Fox Cities. See more here.
  • Veterans Affairs centers. The Milwaukee VA Center is calling eligible veterans and offering appointments. Vets are advised not to call for an appointment, but can go to va.gov to express interest in getting vaccinated.
questions.linkOne: Where can you get the vaccine in Wisconsin? Here are the different places where vaccinations may be available

questions.category: Where can I get the vaccine?
questions.question: I don’t have health insurance or a regular doctor. How do I get vaccinated?
questions.answer:
You don’t need health insurance to get the vaccine. If you don’t have a regular doctor, you can try getting the vaccine through one of your local pharmacies, your local or tribal health department or a community health center. Check their websites or social media pages to find information on how to register or where to go to get the vaccine.

Walgreens locations in Wisconsin are receiving vaccine through a federal program meant to speed up vaccinations for eligible groups. Anyone who is eligible can register at walgreens.com/findcare/vaccination/covid-19 or by calling 1-800-925-4733.

Several local communities and the state have set up community vaccination clinics.

State-sponsored vaccine clinics are opening around the state, in Rock County, Racine and La Crosse. A fourth will be opening in Marathon County soon, and a fifth will be split between Douglas and Barron counties. Appointments can be made at vaccinate.wi.gov

If you’re in the Fox Cities, you can schedule an appointment at sites in Appleton or Oshkosh.

  • Appleton: Fox Cities Exhibition Center, 355 W. Lawrence St.
    Visit foxcitiescovidvaccine.com or call 920-399-2550  
  • Oshkosh: Culver Family Welcome Center on the UW-Oshkosh campus, 625 Pearl Ave.
    Visit uwosh.edu/titans-return/vaccination

questions.question: How much does the vaccine cost?
questions.answer:
You should not have to pay anything to get the vaccine. People without health insurance or whose insurance does not provide coverage of the vaccine can get the COVID-19 vaccine at no cost. 

There have been reports of some vaccine providers charging people for vaccine appointments, but in at least one case, the provider stopped charging the fee after it came to light and after warnings the state could cut off their vaccine supply.

questions.question: Which vaccine will I get? What are the differences?
questions.answer:
The vaccine you get will depend on which provider you go to. There are three vaccines authorized for use in the United States – one from Pfizer-BioNTech, one from Moderna and one from Johnson & Johnson.

Pfizer
  • mRNA vaccine
  • Given in a two-dose series, three weeks apart.
  • Authorized for people 16 and older.
  • Found to be around 95% effective at preventing COVID-19 illness.
Moderna
  • mRNA vaccine
  • Given in a two-dose series, four weeks apart.
  • Authorized for people 18 and older.
  • Found to be around 95% effective at preventing COVID-19 illness.
Johnson & Johnson
  • An adenovirus-based vaccine
  • Requires only one shot
  • Globally, found to be 66% effective against moderate to severe Covid-19 cases four weeks after inoculation. In the U.S, the vaccine showed 72% efficacy. It was 86% protective against severe forms of the disease.
questions.linkOne: Pfizer, Moderna, J&J? Most in Wisconsin won't be given a choice of COVID-19 vaccine — and doctors say that's OK

questions.question: How do the vaccines work?
questions.answer:
The Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are messenger RNA (or mRNA) vaccines. They give our cells instructions to make the spike protein that is found on the surface of the novel coronavirus and helps it attach to cells.

Once it's built, our immune systems recognize that it doesn't belong there and begin to fight it off — teaching our bodies how to protect against future infection. After the process is finished, the cell gets rid of the instructions it used to create the protein in the first place.

This is the first time that an mRNA vaccine has been officially authorized to treat a disease, but it's not really new. Scientists have been studying the method for decades. And it doesn’t permanently alter your DNA, as some have floated – in fact, it doesn’t involve your DNA at all, and actually leaves no trace in the body once those instructions get deleted.

The Johnson & Johnson vaccine is an adenovirus-based vaccine. Scientists combined a piece of genetic material from the coronavirus spike protein with an adenovirus, which causes colds or flu-like symptoms.

This virus can enter cells, but can’t replicate inside them or cause illness – in other words, you will not contract the virus from this vaccine. Once inside your body, the immune system will begin targeting and fighting off the spike proteins, learning to recognize them in the future if the real coronavirus comes in.

questions.question: How effective is the vaccine?
questions.answer:
The Pfizer and Moderna vaccines, both of which require two shots, were found to be about 95% effective at preventing COVID-19.

The one-shot Johnson & Johnson vaccine was found to be 66% effective at preventing COVID-19 cases by two weeks after inoculation, and highly effective at preventing severe disease and death. No clinical trial participants who got sick at least four weeks after inoculation had to be hospitalized.

Experts caution that comparing effectiveness numbers of the three vaccines is problematic because they were tested at different times in different groups of people.

questions.question: Can I get a mammogram if I got the COVID vaccine?
questions.answer:
Because some women can get experience swollen lymph nodes following vaccination and confuse that for breast lumps, doctors recommend they schedule their mammogram before receiving a COVID-19 vaccine, or space out the two appointments.

These swollen lymph nodes can also show up in mammograms. The ones located under the armpits are most likely to swell after vaccination because they’re closest to the injection site. The swelling could begin as soon as a few days after vaccination and could last as long as 12 weeks.

Guidelines from the MD Anderson Cancer Center recommend waiting to do a mammogram four to six weeks after receiving a vaccine.

questions.question: Should anyone not get the vaccine?
questions.answer:
People who have had a severe or immediate allergic reaction to any ingredient in the vaccine should not get it. If you had a severe or immediate allergic reaction after getting the first dose of a vaccine, the CDC recommends that you not get the second dose.

For information on the Pfizer vaccine’s ingredients, go here. For information on the Moderna vaccine’s ingredients, go here.

Vaccine providers should observe you for 15-30 minutes after you receive the vaccine to be able to respond to any reaction. The CDC is monitoring reports of severe allergic reactions in a small number of vaccine recipients.

questions.question: What are the side effects?
questions.answer:
Side effects are usually mild to moderate and go away within a few days. Common side effects include pain at the injection site, fatigue, headache and muscle pain. People may also experience chills, fever, joint pain or swelling at the injection site. Side effects are more common after the second dose of the vaccine.

A small number of people have had a severe allergic reaction, called anaphylaxis, after vaccination, but this is rare and treatable.
questions.linkOne: COVID-19 vaccine side effects are more likely to happen after the second shot. Here's what I experienced when I got mine.

questions.question: Has anyone died from the vaccine?
questions.answer:
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has not linked any deaths to the vaccines. The CDC investigates reports of death to determine if they were vaccine-related.

More than 38 million people in the U.S. received at least one dose of the vaccine in the first two months it was available, and in that time, the government received 934 reports of death among vaccine recipients in the U.S. Those deaths could be entirely coincidental. Last year, an average of around 9,000 people died per day.

The New York Times has reported on a Florida doctor who died after receiving the vaccine and developing an unusual blood disorder that some experts say could be an exceedingly rare reaction to the vaccine. The CDC has said rates of the disorder in vaccinated people did not appear higher than the rates normally found in the U.S. population, indicating those cases might not be linked to the vaccine. The CDC is investigating the doctor’s death.

The vaccines are considered safe, and severe reactions are rare.

related.relatedHeadline: With vaccines rolling out but variants rising, we're at 'a critical juncture' in COVID-19 pandemic
related.relatedBrief: As the world approaches a second spring in the throes of the COVID-19 pandemic, ramped up vaccinations and the emergence of frightening variants of the new coronavirus are offering two contradictory visions of the future.
